1. Vingegaard in yellow, Pogaƒçar clawing back seconds

Vingegaard, who won the 2022 Tour de France by 2:43sec over Pogaƒçar, holds the yellow jersey on the first rest day. The Dane gained time over his main rival on Stage 5 from Pau to Laruns, which was won by Jai Hindley (Bora-Hansgrohe) but the distance between Vingegaard and Pogaƒçar was the bigger talking point. Vingegaard finished 38 seconds down on Hindley but Pogaƒçar was a further minute behind. Was this already the end of his GC battle?

Of course not. This is cycling and anything can happen. The next day Jumbo-Visma swarmed a lonely Pogaƒçar over the summit of the Col du Tourmalet, working hard for their queen bee. It was down to the two; mano a mano.

Alongside a flare-flaling fan dripping in polka dots, with less than 3km remaining Pogaƒçar attacked. Vingegaard tried to respond but was forced to take things at his own pace. 2. Mark Cavendish crashes out of final Tour de France

Mark Cavendish announced earlier this season that he would retire at the end of the 2023 season and came into the Tour de France level on the stage wins record with Eddy Merckx. This would be his final Tour, a race that has brought so much success for the Manx Missile.

Over the years, it is not unfair to say Cavendish has presented a stony demeanour peppered with a ‚Äòwin at all costs‚Äô mentality. However, the last few seasons of his career have been different. A more mellow, embracing Cavendish has spent his final Tour de France beaming, high-fiving fans and shooting basketballs, joking before mountain stages that viewers wouldn‚Äôt see him feature in until the end of the day. Former leadout man Mark Renshaw recently joined his Astana Qazaqstan team to aid his leadout train, albeit from the sidelines. Pieces of the puzzle began to fall together.

On Stage 5 into Bordeaux, it looked as if the dream would come true. Cavendish kicked, surging ahead of his adversaries. Was he about to take the record outright? Mark Cavendish, on the cusp of stage win number 35, with the finish line beckoning and that familiar sight of nothing but space in front of him, was scuppered by gear issues and, not able to maintain his acceleration, a storming Jasper Philipsen swooped past to win his third stage of this year‚Äôs Tour de France.

After the finish, Cavendish said, ‚ÄòThe gears jumped from the 11 to the 12, I had to sit down. The cadence just whacks up. Then it goes back to the 11th. I tried to stand up. I needed to sit down. There was nothing you could do except kind of hope.‚Äô

Just a few days later, on Stage 8 from Libourne to Limoges, a ripple effect swept its way through the peloton. A common occurrence in cycling, nothing out of the ordinary. On a quiet part of a quiet stage. But then cameras cut to Cavendish on the ground. Since the pace hadn‚Äôt been high when the incident happened, surely he‚Äôd get a new bike from the mechanic and be on his way? Optimism drained the longer images remained the same. After a few minuites of doubt, Cavendish was in the back of an ambulance, collarbone broken, forced to abandon. Questions immediately followed on whether this would actually be his final Tour de France given the nature in which it ended. Astana Qazaqstan team manager Alexandre Vinokourov told L‚ÄôEquipe that he is prepared to offer him an extension. Now we wait.

3. The return of the Puy de D√¥me

To go back further, it‚Äôs the scene of the iconic showdown between Raymond Poulidor and Jacques Anquetil in 1964. Anquetil, the defending champion, led the general classification by 56 seconds from Poulidor with two stages remaining. Attack after attack ensued. While Federico Bahamontes and Julio Jimenez were ahead and fought for the stage win, Anquetil and Poulidor only had eyes for one another. Poulidor, so often second to his rival, eked out a gap. Anquetil finished 42 seconds down but won the Tour, it was Poulidor‚Äôs first of three second places.

Fast forward to 2023 and Matteo Jorgenson was out in front, the peloton over 15 minutes behind and content to let the breakaway battle for victory. Michael Woods was in a group two minutes behind Jorgenson at the bottom of the climb but he was the man to beat and began picking off the riders in front with ease. Jorgenson looked to be pedalling through treacle in comparison, exhaustion evident in his demeanour. Woods caught and passed the American to win his first Tour de France stage before eyes turned to the GC group. In the final kilometre, Pogaƒçar put the hammer down and dropped Vingegaard on the savage 14% gradient to snatch back eight seconds.
